This system monitor shows you graphs that lag 5 seconds behind the actual information (that is shown right below those graphs!). It's also not possible to switch between "one graph per CPU core/thread" and "one graph for all", even though a chart for a "just" 16-threaded CPU is plain unreadable. Sorry to say but Windows does that way better for decades now, not sure why no one ever bothered to replicate that for Gnome.

Since this app doesn't run as root, it doesn't show a complete picture of what's going on in the system. IF you run as root (sudo gnome-system-monitor) then it does show the information you're looking for.

Also, doesn't graph IO, which is often what I need to see. Adding this feature would make the app so much more useful... ;)
Whenever I launch the app, whether from the Terminal or the UI, it seemingly opens on a screen that does not exist.

Will never tell you which process consumes all the internet bandwidth.
How can a system monitor be missing such an essential feature?
Slow to load on older systems, which is a shame as lauching this usually meansthe user wants to check or kill a process quickly
Great app. Would be nice to have the graphical network monitor as a separate standalone app.

"The problem you are seeing is with mutter/gnome-shell being inefficient at frequently-updating software rendered windows. This is a known problem, but until now we only knew of Eclipse triggering it (bug 1756508), and the older pre-Quantum versions of Firefox (bug 1696305).

What you are seeing is a known performance problem, but you have discovered a great test case for it in the Resources tab. So thanks.

As I suspected, this is not a problem with the new Firefox at all (which is hardware rendered). It's a problem with gnome-system-monitor, or any frequently-redrawing software rendered (e.g. Gnome) app."

"

AFAIK, gnome-system-monitor is one of those rare apps which are software rendered (because GTK) but also try to animate at a smooth frame rate.

It's a rare combination and a useful test case."

https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-shell/+bug/1773502

I'm glad for Gnome devs that they found a good test case, but what about fixing the program?
summary: Used as a test case for a "known performance problem" in Gnome

description: Its a good app but ive experienced consinstant stutter when I have it on.

Windows task manager > Details then right click on your program Set Affinity .

In the last 3 months, I've installed bionic at least 4 or 5 times, and 20.04 once, and I don't believe this has failed me once.. (unless it's due to mostly when on this 15-20 yr old Inspiron 1525 w/ 1GB RAM and more than a few windows open.. but then everything gives me trouble)
That makes me find it *Incredibly* difficult that it doesn't work on bionic. I'd have to a brain in a vat or alien VR or whatever with false memories. Much more likely the pebcac.
Yes, it could be better (if it were exactly like procexp..?) but seems to do the job as needed, just a little less bells and whistles and the years of polish and whatnot procexp gets from the undoubtedly highly knowledgeable and skilled creator of the Sysutils.

It works just fine, shows (most of) all system info you'd expect to find... except for ONE thing- it only shows the cpu usage for individual cores, I can't see percent usage out of all cpu cores combined (at least to my knowledge).

Just what we need in a system monitor! Lack of excessive details, functionality and keyboard controls. Excellent wow good job, please strip away more things because my eyes ache from seeing all this information 
( If you are searching for a good system monitor, check out KDE Plasma's system monitor app. Yes you'll probably have to install at least plasma-core, and the window won't integrate well with Gnome at all, but at least you'll be able to see more information, like data transfer speeds per process, usage graphs per process, processes grouped by application, and have a lot of customizability. )

Does it work? Sure. It provides very basic funtionality. Nothing more.
No real-time GPU, disk usage is a major pain point.

Also, it looks incredibly outdated and difficult to read. I understand it's free software. But there is major room for improvement from a UI/UX perspective.
